properties.name: Goulburn River
properties.description: The Goulburn River is large tailwater that flows from the Lake Eildon Pondage. The river flows clear and has a freestone bottom with a mixture of weed beds and occasional timber. It flows through flat farmland with intermittent riparian vegetation, often in the form of willows...

properties.name: Blue Rock Dam
properties.description: A large water storage located east of Melbourne next to the town of Willow Grove. The lake is fed by the Tanjil River which has some very good fishing both above and below the dam...

properties.name: Deepwater River
properties.description: Deepwater River is a small-to-medium sized perennial stream in the Northern Tablelands district of New South Wales. It runs through the small town of Deepwater, which has amenities for travelling anglers...

properties.name: Guy Fawkes River
properties.description: The Guy Fawkes River is a perennial stream in the New England and Northern Tablelands districts of New South Wales. The river is a small meandering stream that winds its way down from its headwaters near the Great Escarpment, through farmland and the township of Ebor, and over the Ebor Falls...

properties.name: Authurs Lake
properties.description: One of the most well know and popular fisheries in Tasmania’s central plates, Arthurs lake is a large body of water managed for hydro electricity generation. It holds a large population of wild brown trout that are self sustaining, spawning in the many creeks and streams running into the lake...

properties.name: Bronte Lagoon
properties.description: There are great grassy shorelines around the lake that you can expect to find tailing trout along, so long as the water level is high. Early season wet fly fishing is very good, with plenty of structure to focus on including weed beds, rocky shorelines, points and fallen timber...

properties.name: Brumbys Creek
properties.description: Brumbys Creek is one of Tasmania’s most unique rivers. It is like a tailwater in that it is fed from Great Lake in the Central Highlands via the Poatina Power Station, however, it flows more like a meadow stream...

properties.name: Hunstman Lake
properties.description: Created in 2007, Huntsman Lake is a scenic dam nestled atop of the Meander Valley. The lake is surround by forest and is fed by a number of small streams and holds a large population of small wild brown trout...

properties.name: Huon River
properties.description: The Huon is a big river, being the fifth longest in the state. Initially the river flows through rugged terrain, lower down it becomes more accessible as it moves through farmland and towns before meeting the sea...

properties.name: Lake Burbury
properties.description: Lake Burbury is a large and beautiful waterway on the west coast. It contains a good head of rainbow and brown trout. This lake is typically considered as a venue best fished from a boat, purely because of its size...

properties.name: Lake Leake
properties.description: A scenic lake nestled in the hills of the east coast, Lake Leake is surrounded by lowland forest. Due to its lack of height above sea level, it fishes well early in the season before the water warms too much...

properties.name: Lake St Clair
properties.description: Arguably the most scenic lake in Tasmania and located within the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park, Lake St Clair is a trekking destination as part of the Overland Track and a stunning wild brown and rainbow trout fishery...

properties.name: Little Pine Lagoon
properties.description: Little Pine Lagoon is one of Australia’s best-known wild brown trout fisheries and is dedicated fly-fishing-only water. It is fed from the Little Pine River and releases water down the Monpeelyata Canal to Lake Echo...

properties.name: Macquarie River
properties.description: he Macquarie River is a picturesque slow flowing meadow stream with banks lined by grass and tussocks and some sections of willows. Running through the midlands of Tasmania, this river provides plenty of access to anglers...
